p.seg: The first mountain range in the Classic of the Southern Mountains is called Mount Magpie.
Its first peak is called Mount Raiseshake.
It overlooks the West Sea.
There are numerous cinnamon trees
and a great amount of gold and jade.
There is a plant on this mountain
which looks like an onion, but it has green flowers.
Its name is the praymore.
If you eat it, you won't starve.
There is a tree on the mountain
which looks like the paper mulberry but has black markings.
Its blossoms light up everything around it.
its name is the lost-mulberry.
If you wear it in your belt, you won't get lost.
There is an animal the mountain
which looks like a long-tailed ape, but it has white ears.
It crouches as it moves along and it runs like a human.
Its name is the live-lively.
If you eat it you'll be a good runner.
The River Sveltedeer rises here
and flows westwards to empty into the sea.
It has a lot of breedsurge herbs in it.
If you wear some in your belt, you won't suffer from worms.
Three hundred leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Hallcourt.
It has numerous fruiting shrubs
and many white gibbons.
This mountain has quantities of rock crystal
and yellow gold.
Three hundred and eighy leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Monkeywing.
There are numerous animals on it
and many curious fish in its waterways.
There is plenty of white jade
and numbers of giant snout-snakes,
as well as many strange serpents
and many curious trees.
One cannot climb up this mountain.
Three hundred and seventy leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Cherrysunny.
There are quantities of scarlet gold on its south face,
and plenty of white gold on its north face.
there is an animal on this mountain
which looks like a horse, but it has a white head
and stripes like a tiger, and a scarlet tail.
It makes a noise like the crooning of a human being.
Its name is the stag-silkworm.
If you were some of it in your belt, it will help you to have children and grandchildren.
The River Weird rises here
and flows east to empty into the River Joyouswing.
There are numerous dark turtles in it
which look like water turtles, but they have a bird's head and a snake's tail.
Their name is the whirlyturtle.
They make a noise like wood being split.
If you wear some of it in your belt, you won't go deaf,
and it can be used for caluses.
There are a lot of waterways here,
but no plants or trees.
In these waters there is a fish
which looks like an ox.
It lives in the hillier parts.
It has a snake's tail and wings,
the feathers of which lie below its flanks.
It makes a noise like that of the brindled ox.
Its name is the winged-landfish.
It dies in winter and comes to life in summer.
If you eat it, you won't suffer from swellings.
Four hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount True-drag.
It has plenty of water-ways,
but no plants or trees.
You can't climb up it.
There is an animal here
which looks like a wild cat, but it has longer fur.
Its name is the sort.
It is by nature both male and female.
If you eat some of it, you won't get jealous.
Three hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Base.
there are quantities of jade on its south face
and great numbers of curious trees on its north face.
There is an animal on this mountain
which looks like a ram
with nine tails and four ears.
Its eyes are on its back.
Its name is the muttgabble.
If you wear some of it in your belt you won't feel fear.
There is a bird on the moountain
which looks like a chicken, but it has three heads, six eyes,
six feet and three wings.
Its name is the esteem-add.
If you eat it, you won't keep falling asleep.
Three hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Greenmound.
There is plenty of jadeon its south face,
and a great deal of the finest dark cinnabar on its north face.
There is an animal on this mountain
that looks like a fox, but it has nine tails.
It makes a noise like a baby.
It can devour humans.
Whoever eats it will not be affected by malign forces.
There is a bird on the mountain
which looks like a pigeon.
It makes a noise like an angry shout.
Its name is the pourpour.
If you wear some of it in your belt, you won't suffer from delusions.
The River Brave rises here
and flows south to empty into Reachwing Marsh.
It contains numbers of scarlet scholar-fish
which look like a fish, but they have a human face.
The make a noise like mandarin ducks.
It you eat it you won't itch.
Three hundred and fifty leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Winnowtail.
Its tail end crouches down towards the East Sea.
There is a great amount of sandy gravel there.
The River Spate rises here
and flows south to emtpy into the river Breed.
The River Spate contains quantities of white jade.
In sum, the peaks of Mount Magpie,
from Mount Raiseshake
to Mount Winnowtail
number ten mountains
over a distance of 2.950 leagues.
xxx
In sacrificing to them the ritual is:
use animals with hair of a single colour; use a single jade ceremonial half-tablet, then ritually bury it;
for the sacrificial rice, use sticky rice;
use husked rice;
-In sum, the peaks of Mount Magpie,
from Mount Raiseshake
to Mount Winnowtail
number ten mountains
over a distance of 2.950 leagues.
The deities of these mountains all have the appearance of a bird's body and a dragon's head.
xxx
There is an animal on Mount Teawillow
which looks like a suckling pig
and it has cock spurs.
It makes a noise like a dog barking.
Its name is the wildcat-strength.
Wherever it appreas there will be major earthworks in that district.
There is a bird on this mountain
which looks like an owl, but it has human hands.
It makes a noise like a hen quail.
Its name is the crimsonowl.
Its name comes from its call: 'Joo.'
Wherever it appears, numerous officers will be banished from that district.
Four hundred and fifty leagues further southeast is a mountain
called Mount Longright.
It has no plants or trees
but numerous waterways.
There is an animal on this mount
which looks like a long-tailed ape, but it has four ears.
Its name is the longright.
It makes a noise like the crooning of a human being.
Wherever it appears there will be a major flood in the districts of that commandery.
Three hundred and forty leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Loftyglare.
There is plentiful jade on its south face
and quantities of gold on its noth face.
There is an animal on this mountain
which looks like a human, but it has hog bristles.
It lives in a cave and in winter it hibernates.
Its name is the trickywrap.
It makes a noise like wood being chopped.
Wherever it appears there will be an extensive military draft for that district.
Three hundredand fifty leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Feather.
Below it are numerous waterways,
and there are frequent showers over its summit.
It has no plants or trees,
but numerous giant snout-snakes.
Three hundred and seventy leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Waryfather.
It has no plants or trees,
but a great amount of gold and jade.
Four hundred leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Bendmore.
It has no plants or trees,
but a great amount of gold and jade. (omitted by AB)
Five hundred leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Floatjade.
To the north it looks on the great Lake Storehoard,
and to the east it looks on the River Allnavel.
There is an animal on this mountain
which looks like a tiger, but it has the tail of an ox.
It makes a noise like a dog's bark.
Its name is the hoggy.
It eats humans.
The River Reed rises on its north face
and flows north to empty into Lake Storehoard.
There are numerous swordfish in the River Reed.
Five hundredleagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Success.
It has four sides and three natural earth altars.
On its summit are quantities of god and jade,
and on its lower slopes a great amount of the finest dark cinnabar.
The River Sluice rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Roarspoon.
There is a great deal of yellow gold in the River Sluice.
Five hundredleages further east there is a mountain
called Mount Gathertill.
It has four faces
and on its summit are quantities of gold and jade,
while on its lower slopes there are numerous stones like white jade with red streaks.
The River Spoon rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Quiet.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Pacified.
It has no plants or trees
and great amounts of sandy gravel.
The river Quiet rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Rangemire.
Five hundred leagues further east is a mountain,
called Mount Helperhook.
There are plentiful amounts of gold and jade on its summit.
At its base there are numerous plants and trees,
but no birds or beasts,
nor is there any water.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Wholeshade.
It has no plants or trees,
nor any water.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Weep.
There are quantities of gold on its south face,
and a great deal of jade on its north face.
There is an animal here
which looks like a ram, but it has no mouth
and it can't be killed.
Its name is the wreck-ram.
The River Weep rises here
and flows south to empty into Blockage Marsh.
There are many purple conches in the River Weep.
Four hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Roarspoon.
There are numerous catalpa and wild plum trees on its summit,
and at its base many thorn and willow trees.
The River Rainburst rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Rainburst.
Five hundred leagues further est is a montain
called Mount Hoardcry.
It has no plants or trees,
but great quantities of sandy gravel.
The River Stag rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Rainburst.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Stagcry.
It has no plants or trees on its summit,
but a great deal of gold and stone.
The River Marshchange rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Rainburst.
There is an animal on this mountain.
Its name is the malignforce-buzzard.
It looks like a buzzard but it has horns.
It makes a noise like a baby crying.
It eats humans.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Lacquercry.
It has no plants or trees,
but a great number of gaming stones.
It has no jade.
This mountain is situated in the East Sea
and it looks out onto Mount Mound.
Glaring light arises from it at times, and at times it sets.
This is a station of the sun.
In sum, the peaks of the Classic of the Southern Mountains, Part II,
from Mount Teawillow to Mount Lacquercry,
number seventeen mountains
over a distance of 7200 leagues.
The deities of these mountains all have the appearance of a dragon's body and a bird's head.
Sacrifice to them follows this ritual:
use animals with hair of one colour; use a single ceremonial jade, then ritually bury it;
use sticky rice for the sacrificial rice.
The first peak of the Classic of the Southern Mountains, Part II,
is alled Mount Skyfret.
At its base are numerous waterways.
This mountain cannot be climbed.
Five hundred leagues to the east,
is a mountain called Mount Prayerpass.
There are quantities of gold and jade on its summit,
and at its base are numerous herds of rhinoceros
and elephant.
There is a bird on this mountain
which looks like a small duck,
but it has a white head, three feet, and a human face.
Its name is the warylike.
Its name comes from its call: 'Choo-roo.'
The River Bank rises here
and flows south to empty into the sea.
There are tiger-crocodies in it.
Their bodies look like a fish's, but they have a snake's tail
and they make a noise like mandarin ducks.
If you eat some, you won't suffer from a swollen abscess,
and it can be used to treat piles.
Five hundred leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Cinnabarcave.
There is plenty of gold and jade on its summit.
The river Cinnabar rises here
and flows south to empty into the gulf Sea.
There is a bird on this mountain
which looks like a chicken.
It is five-coloured and has patterned plumage.
Its name is the Divine Wind.
Markings on its back spell 'Virtue'.
Markings on its wings spell 'Justice".
Markings on its back spell 'Ritual'.
Markings on its chest spell 'Humanity'.
Markings on its belly spell 'Faith'.
This bird
provides drink and food from its own self.
It sings for itself and it dances for itself.
Whenever there will be order there will be peace over all under the sky.
Four hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Show-lively.
It has no plants or trees,
but a great amount of water
and numerous white gibbons.
and flows south to empty into the Gulf Sea.
Four hundred leagues further east
brings you to the tail end of Mount Tailbanner.
South of it there is a valley
called Breedheir
which has any number of strange birds.
The pleasing south wind comes from it.
Four hundred leagues further east
brings you to the peak of Mount Wrong.
There is a great amount of gold and jade on its summit,
At its base are numerous giant snout-snakes.
Five hundred leagues further east is a mountain
called Mount Sunny-tight.
It has no plants or trees,
but a great amount of water.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Purroil.
There are numerous trees on its summit
but no plants,
and there are many strange birds,
but no animals.
Five hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Chicken.
there is a quantity of gold on its summit,
and at its base a great amount of the finest cinnabar soil.
the River Black rises there
and flows south to empty into the sea.
It contains numerous sturgeon
which look like perch but have the bristles of a hog.
It makes a noise like a piglet.
Whenever it appears there will be a severe drought over all under the sky.
Four hundred leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Commandmound.
It has no plants or trees,
and it is often on fire.
South of this mountain is a valley
called Middle Valley,
and the high northeast wind comes from it.
There is a bird on this mountain
which looks like an owl.
It has a human face with four eyes, and it has ears.
Its name is the ape-owl.
Its name comes from its call: 'Yoo-hoo.'
Whenever it appears there will be a severe drought over all under the sky.
Three hundred and seventy leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Thinker.
There is a great amount of gold on its summit,
and at its base a qunatity of the finest dark cinnabar.
There is a tree on this mountain
which looks like the paper mulberry tree, but it has scarlet veins
and its sap is like lacquer
and has a sweetish taste.
If you eat some of it you won't starve,
and it can relieve exhaustion from hard work.
Its name is the white perilla.
It can be used to make jade a blood-veined colour.
Five hundred an eighty leagues further east
is a mountain called Mount Southape.
There are qunatities of gold and jade on its summit,
and at its base plenty of water.
There is a cave on this mountain out
from which water gushes out and then suddenly rushes back in.
It gushes out in summer,
and then in winter it is sealed in.
The River Aid rises here
and flows southeast to empty into the sea.
Here there are the Divine Wind bird and the divine Soar Speed bird.
In sum, the peaks in the Classic of the Southern Mountains, Part III,
from Mount Skyfret to Mount Southape,
number fourteen moluntains
over a distance of 6530 leagues.
The deities of these mountains all have a dragon's body and a human face.
Sacrifice to them alwyas follows this ritual:
use a single white dog for the votive offering;
use sticky rice for the sacrificial rice.
In the above treatise on the mountains in the Classic of the Southern Mountains
the total number is forty mountians, both large and small,
over a distance of 16380 leagues.

div.head: 2 西山經第二 In the Classic of the Western Mountains,

p.seg: the first peak of the Mount Blossom range
is Mount Moneycome.
Pine trees are numerous on its summit,
and there are quantities of laundry strones at its base.
there is an animal here
which looks like a ram but it has a horse's tail.
Its name is the goat-antelope.
Its fat can cure chapped skin.
Forty-five leagues to the west
is a mountain called Mount Pinecone.
The River Simmer rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Rapids.
There are quantities of coppier in theRiver Simmer.
There is a bird on this mountain
named the wagtail.
It looks like a mountain fowl;
it has a black body and red feet.
It is effective for wrinkles.
Sixty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Grandblossom.
In formation it is sheer and has four faces.
It is 40 000 feet high
and ten leagues broad.
No birds or animals live on it.
There is a serpent here.
Its name is the plum-remains.
It has six feet and four wings.
Whenever it appears there will be severe drought over all under the sky.
Eighty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Littleblossom.
Its trees are mostly thorn and willow. Its animals are mostly wild buffalo.
There are numerous musical stones on its north face,
and on its south face quantities of yufu jade.
The birds here are mostly scarlet mountain fowl.
They are effective against fire.
Among the plants on this mountain is the dwarf figtree
which looks like rockfern
but it grows over rocks
and it also grows up trees.
If you eat it, it will cure pains in the heart.
Eighty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Tallyape.
There is a great amount of copper on its south face,
and quantities of iron on its north face.
There is a tree on its summit
named the pattern-trunk.
Its fruit is like a jujube.
It is effective for deafness.
The plants on this mountain are mostly a dwarf allium variety,
which looks like a mallow,
but has scarlet flowers and yellow fruit
which looks like a baby's tongue.
Eating it prevents people from suffering from delusions.
The River Tallyape rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Rapids.
The animals on this mountain are mostly the onion-deaf
which are wild goats that look like a ram but have a scarlet mane.
The birds on the mountain are mostly the pie,
which looks like a kingfisher but has a scarlet beak.
It is effective against fire.
Sixty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Stonebrittle.
Its trees are mostly palm and wild plum,
and its plants are mostly dwarf allium
which look like garlic
but have white flowers and black fruit.
If you eat it it is effective for itching.
On the south face of this mountain there are quantities of yufu jade,
and on its north face a great deal of copper.
The River Pour rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Ape.
There is bloodstone floating in the water
which is used to smear an oxen and horses to prevent them from becoming ill.
Seventy leagues further west
is a mountain called mount Brave.
There are numerous holmoak and oak treses on its summit.
There are quantities of iron on its north face
and a great amoun tof scarlet gold on its south face.
The Rive Ape rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Raise.
Freshwater mussels are plentiful in the River Ape.
They look like soft turtles
but make a noise like a ram.
On the north bank of this river there are numerous arrow-bamboos and winter-bamboos.
Among the animals on this mountain are many wild buffalo and antelope.
There is a bird here
which looks like a quail;
it has a yellow body and a red beak.
Its name is the plum-remains.
If you eat it, it will cure boils,
and it is effective for killing insects.
Fifty-two leagues further west is a mountain
called Mount Bamboo.
There are numerous arching trees on its summit.
Irion is plentiful on its north face.
There is a plant here
named the yellow-heron,
which looks like ailanthus.
Its leaves are like hemp,
and it has white flowers and red fruit
which looks like bloodstone.
If you bathe with it it cures itching
and it is effective against swellings.
The River Bamboo rises here
and flows noth to empty into the river Rapids.
There are many arrow-bamboos on the south side of this mountain,
and a great deal of bright blue jade.
The River Cinnabar rises here
and flows southeast to empty into the River Clear.
There is a great deal of rock crystl in the river Cinnabar
and human-fish.
There is an animal on this mountain
which looks like a hog but it has white hair
that is as long as a large hair-pin and black at the tip.
Its name is the porcupine.
A hundred and twenty leagues further West is a mountain called Mount Float.
There are numerous pied-trees on it
which have needles for leaves, but they are harmless.
Tree bugs live in this tree.
There is a plant on this mountain
named the incence-herb.
It has hemp leaves and a square stalk
with scarlet flowers and black fruit.
It has an aroma like the scent-herb.
If you wear it in your belt it is effective for sores.
Seventy leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Ewenext.
The River Lacquer rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Rapids.
Thorn oak are numerous on the mountaintop,
and there are many arrow-bamboos on the lower slopes.
There are great quantities of scarlet copper on the north face,
and numerous collar-wall jade stones on the south face.
There is an animal on this mountain
which looks like an ape, but it has longer arms
and it is good at throwing things.
Its name is the hubbub.
There is a bird here
which looks like an owl;
it has a human face but only one foot.
Its name is the bellows-pot.
It appears in winter and hides in summer.
If you wear some of it you won't be afraid of thunder.
A hundred and fifty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Time.
It has no plants or trees.
The River Chase rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Rapids.
Rock crystal is plentiful in the River Chase.
A hundred and seventy leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount South.
On its summit are quantities of granular cinnabar.
The River Cinnabar rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Rapids.
Among the animals on this mountain are numerous wild leopards.
Its birds are mostly cuckoos.
A hundred and eighty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Bigtime.
Holmoak and oak trees are numerous on its summit.
There are quantities of silver on its north face,
and plentiful white jade on its south face.
The River Torrent rises here
and flows north to emtpy into the River Rapids.
The River Pure rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Han.
Three hundred and twenty leagues further west
The River Han rises here
and flows southeast to empty into the River Flood.
The river Hubbub rises here
and flows north to empty into the River Hotwater.
There are many peachbranch-bamoos and hooktip-bamboos on the mountaintop.
Among the animals here are numerous rhinoceros of two kinds, black bears and brown bears.
The birds are mostly white pheasants and golden pheasants speckled with scarlet.
There is a plant on this mountain
with leaves like an orchid.
Its roots are like a well-thorn shrub.
It has black flowers but it doesn't fruit.
Its name is the jungle-hibiscus.
If humans eat it, they won't have children.
Three hundred and fifty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Skygod.
Many palm and wild plum trees are on its summit,
and on the lower slopes numerous reeds and hibiscus.
There is an animal here
that looks like dog.
Its name is the beckside.
If you use its skin as a seat you won't be affected by
There is a bird here
which looks like a quail,
but it black markings and a scarfelt ruff.
Its name is the chestnut-oak.
If you eat it you will be cured of piles.
There is a plant here
which looks like a mallow;
it has an aroma like the scent-herb.
Its name is the pear-asarum.
It is effective for making horses go,
and if you eat it, it will cure the goitre.
Three hundred and eightyleagues further west
The River Redrose rises here
and flows west to empty into the river Allgoods.
The Rivber Mire rises here
and flows south to empty into the River choicecatch.
Granular cinnabar is plentiful on the south face of this mountain,
and there are great quantities of silver and gold on its north face.
There are many crimson trees on the summit.
There is a white stone here
named the poisonstone.
It is effective for poisoning rats.
There is a plant here
which looks like a hay root;
its leaves are like a mallow but their underside is scarlet.
Its name is the stemless [TWIGLESS C.H.].
It is effective for poisoning rats.
There is an animal here
which looks like a stag, but it has a white tail,
horse's hoofs, and human hands, and it has four horns.
Its name is the gibbon-like.
There is a bird here
that looks like kite but it has human feet.
Its name is the count-such.
If you eat it, you will be cured of a goitre.
A hundred and eighty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Yellow.
It has no plants or trees,
except for numerous arrow-bamboos.
The River Gaze rises here
and flows west to emtpy into River Scarlet.
There is a greast deal of jade in the River Gaze.
There is an animal here
which looks like an ox
but it is a bluing-black colour and it has large eyes.
Its name is the busy.
There is a bird here
that looks like an owl
but it has green feathers and a red beak;
it has a human tongue and can talk.
its name is the parrot.
Two hundred leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Kingfisher.
Numerous palms and wild plum trees are on its summit,
and many arrow-bamboos are on the lower slopes.
There are quantities of yellow gold and jade on the south face.
On its north face are many grunting-ox, antelope, and musk deer.
Among its birds are numerous birth-in-flight-birds
which look like a magpiebut
are scarlet and black; they have two heads and four feet.
They are effective against fire.
Two hundred and fifty leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Blueroanhorse.
This mountain serves as a metal barrier against the West Sea.
There are no plants or trees here,
but plentiful jade.
The River Rue rises here
and flows west to empty into the Sea.
This river contains many coloured stones, besides yellow gold
and much cinnabar.
In sum, the peaks of the classic of the Mountains of the West
from Mount Moneycome to Mount Blueroanhorse,
number nineteen mountains
over a distance of 2,957 leagues.
Mount Blossom is the sacrificial mound.
The sacrificial rite
is that of the Major Sacrifice.
Mount Ewe[next] is the presiding deity.
In sacrificing to them, the ritual is: use torches;
observe a purification period of one hundred days; use one hundred animals of a single colour for the sacrifice, then bury them;
use one hundred lapis lazuli;
for the wine ritual, serve it in one hundred jars;
for the pendants use one hundred ritual oblong jades and one hundred ritual round jades.
The remaining seventeen mountains after these two
each receives a sacrifice, the ritual for which is: use one ram of a single colour;
for the torches use bundles of the hundred plants which are burned, and before they turn to ash, are still glowing;
for the ritual mat seats use white rush bordered with multicoloured silks.
The first peak of the Classic of the Western Mountains, Part II,
is called Mount Sealstamp.C
Copper is plentiful on the summit
and on the lower slopes there is a great deal of jade.
Its trees are mostly holmoak and oak.
TTwo hundred leagues to the west
is a mountain called Mount Greatrisk.
There are great quantities of gold on the south face,
and plentiful iron on the north face.
The River Wash rises here
and flows east to empty into the Great River.
The River Wash contains a large amount of coloured, veined jade pieces,
and numerous white snakes.
A hundred an seventy leagues further west
is a mountain called Mount Countstage.
Yellow gold is plentiful on the summit,
and plentiful iron on the north face.
There are many holmoak and oak trees.
Among its birds are numerous p;arrots.
The River Thorn rises here
and flows south to empty into the River Rapids.
There are quantities of white pearls in the River Thorn.
A hundred and fifty leagues further west is Mont High.
Silver is plentiful on the summit,
and there is a great deal of dark green jade and male-yellow arsenic sulphide on the lower slopes.
Its trees are mostly palm,
and its plants mostly bamboo.
The River Flowthrough rises here
and flows east to empty into the River Rapids.
Chiming stones and dark green jade are numerous in the River Flowthrough.
Three hundred lagues southwest
is a mountain called Mount Girlsbed.
There are quantities of scarlet copper on its south face
and alunite is plentiful on its north face.
Among its animals are numerous tigers, leopards, and two kinds of rhinoceros.
There is a bird here
which looks like a pheasant and it has multicoloured markings.
Its name is the Wonderbird.
